standard_metadata.standard_description: Add, subtract, multiply, and divide decimals to hundredths, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Divide decimals by whole numbers visually

question.content: **Divide.**   *You may use the models shown to help find the quotient.*    ${}=0.96 \div6$

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 96 squares are shaded.

hints.content: We can divide the $9$ tenths into $6$ groups so that each group gets $1$ tenth.  [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]] [[☃ image 4]] [[☃ image 5]] [[☃ image 6]]

images.alt: Six identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. The first square has 10 parts shaded.
The second square has 10 parts shaded.
The third square has 10 parts shaded.
The fourth square has 10 parts shaded.
The fifth square has 10 parts shaded.
The sixth square has 10 parts shaded.

hints.content: We will have $3$ tenths and $6$ hundredths remaining, which is the same as $36$ hundredths. We can divide the $36$ hundredths evenly between $6$ groups.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 36 squares are shaded.

hints.content: Dividing $36$ hundredths between $6$ groups will give each group $6$ hundredths in addition to $1$ tenth.  [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]] [[☃ image 4]] [[☃ image 5]] [[☃ image 6]]  When we divide $\blueD{0.96}$ into $6$ equal-sized groups, we get $16$ hundredths in each group.

images.alt: Six identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first square 16 parts are shaded.
In the second square 16 parts are shaded.
In the third square 16 parts are shaded.
In the fourth square 16 parts are shaded.
In the fifth square 16 parts are shaded.
In the sixth square 16 parts are shaded.

question.content: **Divide.**   *You may use the models shown to help find the quotient.*   $0.42 \div3=$

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 42 squares are shaded.

hints.content: We can divide the $4$ tenths into $3$ groups so that each group gets $1$ tenth.   [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]]

images.alt: Three identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first square 10 parts are shaded.
In the second square 10 parts are shaded.
In the third square 10 parts are shaded.

hints.content: We will have $1$ tenth and $2$ hundredths remaining, which is the same as $12$ hundredths. We can divide the $12$ hundredths evenly between $3$ groups.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 12 squares are shaded.

hints.content: Dividing $12$ hundredths between $3$ groups will give each group $4$ hundredths in addition to $1$ tenth.  [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]]  When we divide $\blueD{0.42}$ into $3$ equal-sized groups, we get $14$ hundredths in each group.

images.alt: Three identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first square 14 parts are shaded.
In the second square 14 parts are shaded.
In the third square 14 parts are shaded.

question.content: **Divide.**   *You may use the models shown to help find the quotient.*     ${}=0.65 \div5$

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 65 squares are shaded.

hints.content: We can divide the $6$ tenths into $5$ groups so that each group gets $1$ tenth.   [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]] [[☃ image 4]] [[☃ image 5]]

images.alt: Five identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first square 10 parts are shaded.
In the second square 10 parts are shaded.
In the third square 10 parts are shaded.
In the fourth square 10 parts are shaded.
In the fifth square 10 parts are shaded.

hints.content: We will have $1$ tenth and $5$ hundredths remaining, which is the same as $15$ hundredths. We can divide the $15$ hundredths evenly between $5$ groups.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 15 squares are shaded.

hints.content: Dividing $15$ hundredths between $5$ groups will give each group $3$ hundredths in addition to $1$ tenth.    [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]] [[☃ image 4]] [[☃ image 5]]    When we divide $\blueD{0.65}$ into $5$ equal-sized groups, we get $13$ hundredths in each group.

images.alt: Five identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first square 13 parts are shaded.
In the second square 13 parts are shaded.
In the third square 13 parts are shaded.
In the fourth square 13 parts are shaded.
In the fifth square 13 parts are shaded.

question.content: **Divide.**   *You may use the models shown to help find the quotient.*   $0.88 \div2=$

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 88 squares are shaded.

hints.content: We can divide the $8$ tenths into $2$ groups so that each group gets $4$ tenths.  [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: Two identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first squares 40 parts are shaded.
In the second squares 40 parts are shaded.

hints.content: We will have $8$ hundredths remaining. We can divide the $8$ hundredths evenly between $2$ groups.  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 8 squares are shaded.

hints.content: Dividing $8$ hundredths between $2$ groups will give each group $4$ hundredths in addition to $4$ tenths.  [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]]    When we divide $\blueD{0.88}$ into $2$ equal-sized groups, we get $44$ hundredths in each group.

images.alt: Two identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first square 44 parts are shaded.
In the second square 44 parts are shaded.

question.content: **Divide.**   *You may use the models shown to help find the quotient.*    $= 0.5 \div2$

images.alt:
A square divided into 10 equally-sized columns to show tenths. 5 columns are shaded and 5 columns
are not shaded.

hints.content: First, let's divide the grid that shows $\blueD{0.5}$ into hundredths.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{5\text { tenths}}$ is equal to $\blueD{50\text { hundredths}}$:  $\blueD{0.5}=\blueD{0.50}$

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 50 squares are shaded.

hints.content: We can divide the $50$ hundredths into $2$ groups so that each group gets $25$ hundredths.  [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]]  When we divide $\blueD{0.5}$ into $2$ equal-sized groups, we get $25$ hundredths in each group.

images.alt: Two identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first square 25 parts are shaded.
In the second square 25 parts are shaded.

question.content: **Divide.**   *You may use the models shown to help find the quotient.*   $0.6 \div3=$

images.alt: A square is divided into 10 equally-sized columns to show tenths. 6 columns are shaded and 4 columns are not shaded.

hints.content: We can divide the $6$ tenths into $3$ groups so that each group gets $2$ tenths.   [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]]

images.alt: Three identical squares. Each square is divided into 10 equally-sized columns to show tenths. In the first square 2 columns are shaded and 8 columns are not shaded.
In the second square 2 columns are shaded and 8 columns are not shaded.
In the third square 2 columns are shaded and 8 columns are not shaded.

hints.content: When we divide $\blueD{0.6}$ into $3$ equal-sized groups, we get $2$ tenths in each group.

question.content: **Divide.**   *You may use the models shown to help find the quotient.*     $=0.4 \div5$

images.alt:
A square divided into 10 equally-sized columns to show tenths. 4 columns are shaded and 6 columns
are not shaded.

hints.content: First, let's divide the grid that shows $\blueD{0.4}$ into hundredths.  [[☃ image 1]]  $\blueD{4\text { tenths}}$ is equal to $\blueD{40\text { hundredths}}$:  $\blueD{0.4}=\blueD{0.40}$

images.alt: A square divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. 40 squares are shaded.

hints.content: We can divide the $40$ hundredths into $5$ groups so that each group gets $8$ hundredths.  [[☃ image 1]] [[☃ image 2]] [[☃ image 3]] [[☃ image 4]] [[☃ image 5]]    When we divide $\blueD{0.4}$ into $5$ equal-sized groups, we get $8$ hundredths in each group.

images.alt: Five identical squares. Each square is divided into 100 equal-sized smaller squares, arranged in 10 rows of 10 squares each to represent 100 parts that equal 1 whole. In the first square 8 parts are shaded.
In the second square 8 parts are shaded.
In the third square 8 parts are shaded.
In the fourth square 8 parts are shaded.
In the fifth square 8 parts are shaded.

question.content: **Divide.**   *You may use the models shown to help find the quotient.*     $=0.6 \div2$

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 5 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark with a dot at 0.6, 3 unlabeled tick marks, and an ending tick mark at 1. Two equal in length arrows are above the number line. First arrow begins at 0 and ends at the third unlabeled tick mark. Second arrow begins at the third unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.6.

hints.content: Each interval on the number line is $\greenD{0.1}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 5 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark with a blue dot at 0.6, 3 unlabeled tick marks, and an ending tick mark at 1. An arrow labeled 0.1 begins at the fifth unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.6.

hints.content: We can count the intervals and see that each of the $\greenD2$ pieces is made up of $3$ intervals, or $0.3$.    [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 5 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark with a dot at 0.6, 3 unlabeled tick marks, and an ending tick mark at 1. Two equal in length arrows are above the number line. First arrow begins at 0 and ends at the third unlabeled tick mark. Second arrow begins at the third unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.6.

question.content: **Divide.**   *Hint: Use the number line below to divide $0.9$ into $3$ equal-sized groups.*     $=0.9\div3$

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 8 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark with a dot at 0.9, and an ending tick mark at 1. Three equal in length arrows are above the number line. First arrow begins at 0 and ends at the third unlabeled tick mark. Second arrow begins at the third unlabeled tick mark and ends at the sixth unlabeled tick mark. Third arrow begins at the sixth unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.9.

hints.content: Each interval on the number line is $\greenD{0.1}$.     [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 8 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark with a blue dot at 0.9, and an ending tick mark at 1. An arrow labeled 0.1 begins at the eighth unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.9.

hints.content: We can count the intervals and see that each of the $\greenD3$ pieces is made up of $3$ intervals, or $0.3$.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 8 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark with a blue dot at 0.9, and an ending tick mark at 1. Three equal in length arrows are above the number line. First arrow begins at 0 and ends at the third unlabeled tick mark. Second arrow begins at the third unlabeled tick mark and ends at the sixth unlabeled tick mark. Third arrow begins at the sixth unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.9.

question.content: **Divide.**   *Hint: Use the number line below to divide $0.8$ into $4$ equal-sized groups.*   $0.8\div4=$

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 7 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark at 0.8, 1 unlabeled tick mark, and an ending tick mark at 1. Four equal in length arrows are above the number line. First arrow begins at 0 and ends at the second unlabeled tick mark. Second arrow begins at the second unlabeled tick mark and ends at the fourth unlabeled tick mark. Third arrow begins at the fourth unlabeled tick mark and ends at the sixth unlabeled tick mark. Fourth arrow begins at the sixth unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.8.

hints.content: Each interval on the number line is $\greenD{0.1}$.   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 7 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark with a blue dot at 0.8, 1 unlabeled tick mark, and an ending tick mark at 1. An arrow labeled 0.1 begins at the seventh unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.8.

hints.content: We can count the intervals and see that each of the $\greenD4$ pieces is made up of $2$ intervals, or $0.2$.      [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, 7 unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark at 0.8, 1 unlabeled tick mark, and an ending tick mark at 1. Four equal in length arrows are above the number line. First arrow begins at 0 and ends at the second unlabeled tick mark. Second arrow begins at the second unlabeled tick mark and ends at the fourth unlabeled tick mark. Third arrow begins at the fourth unlabeled tick mark and ends at the sixth unlabeled tick mark. Fourth arrow begins at the sixth unlabeled tick mark and ends at 0.8.

question.content: **Divide.**   *Hint: Use the number line below to divide $0.32$ into $4$ equal-sized groups.*   $0.32\div4=$

images.alt: number line with 4 equal jumps starting at 0 and ending at 0.32

hints.content: Each interval on the number line is $\maroonD{0.01}$.

images.alt: the same number line with the distance between ticks labeled plus 0.01

hints.content: We can count the intervals and see that each of the $4$ pieces is made up of $8$ intervals, or $\greenE{0.08}$.

images.alt: the same number line with each jump labeled plus 0.08

question.content: **Divide.**   *Hint: Use the number line below to divide $0.60$ into $5$ equal-sized groups.*    $=0.60\div 5$

images.alt: number line with 5 equal jumps starting at 0 and ending at 0.60

hints.content: Each interval on the number line is $\maroonD{0.01}$.

images.alt: the same number line with the distance between ticks labeled plus 0.01

hints.content: We can count the intervals and see that each of the $5$ pieces is made up of $12$ intervals, or $\greenE{0.12}$.

images.alt: the same number line with each jump labeled plus 0.12

question.content: **Divide.**   *Hint: Use the number line below to divide $0.42$ into $3$ equal-sized groups.*   $0.42\div 3=$

images.alt: number line with 3 equal jumps starting at 0 and ending at 0.42

hints.content: Each interval on the number line is $\maroonD{0.01}$.

images.alt: the same number line with the distance between ticks labeled plus 0.01

hints.content: We can count the intervals and see that each of the $3$ pieces is made up of $14$ intervals, or $\greenE{0.14}$.

images.alt: the same number line with each jump labeled plus 0.14
